bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, August 26, 1941

div1.p: Hench discusses the Cornwell painting and an upcoming "Hygeia" article based on his speech at the unveiling. He thinks it appropriate for Moran to be depicted in a military uniform in the painting.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, August 26, 1941
div1.opener:
August 26, 1941
Mr. George A. Kellogg
257 Cornelison Avenue
Jersey City, N. J.
My dear Mr. Kellogg:
div1.p:
By now you have the various suggestions of myself, General Truby and
General Kean regarding the naming of the anonymous figures in the painting and
I assume that you will yourself be sending a copy to Fishbein. I am waiting to
hear about your final decision because I am not sending my final manuscript of
my talk until I hear from you as I will want to put in the extra name in the
last paragraph of my talk where I mention the other men.

My talk is divided into two parts--the first couple of pages are to go,
I believe, with a news description of the painting; the rest of it is to be used
as my paper. It has been edited slightly and is ready for Fishbein as soon as
I hear from you.

I am sending you a copy of a very nice letter I just got from Fred
Rankin. He really sounds enthusiastic and I am sure you will be able to call
on him for whatever help you want. To interest him further, you might send him
copies of the three paintings already made.

Just yesterday I received the two engraver's proofs and they are really
splendid. To say that I am greatly flattered to receive the proofs numbers 1
and 2 is to put it mildly. I am very proud but do think you should have sent
the first ones to others who deserve them more. I am selfish enough not to want
to give one away. I am going to put one in my office at the Clinic and one in my
library at home. I most sincerely thank you for them, also for the very generous
supply of colored prints from the newspaper. Did you send one of these to Moran?
If not, I should like to do so. I will send the others to people whom I know
are not on your list but who have been much interested in the yellow fever story.

I appreciate greatly your offer to pay for a thousand reprints of my
Hygeia article with the news article and colored insert. You really embarrass
me by your kindness and I don't think I ought to accept that offer, but I will
send these out to various men in institutions in connection with my campaign to
try to raise money for the memorialization of Camp Lazear, and if you don't think
you can spare that many I will take advantage of buying a thousand reprints at
the rate for the last thousand rather than that for the first thousand.

By the way, I want to correct the slight error in one of my previous
letters when I was visualizing your McDowell painting. I said that I could just
see him operating on his patient, and then by a misprint it indicated that I thought
his patient was a man. I know my medical history better than that--I know that
it was a woman and don't want you to catch me up on that:

closer.seg:
P. S. I have checked up on Moran's rank. Kissinger was a private
before the episode but was later promoted to acting hospital steward with
a rank of sergeant. Moran had already been acting hospital steward with a
rank of sergeant but had been dropped on July 2, 1900 to become a civilian
clerk in the headquarters of General Fitzhugh Lee. It was while he was
in this capacity that he volunteered to Reed and was kept on as a civilian
clerk until February, 1901, all through the time he was at Camp Lazear.
Strictly speaking, therefore, he was not a soldier when he volunteered but
as he had been just a few weeks before, it seems entirely justified to have
him in uniform and to consider him one of the two first “soldiers” who
volunteered.
P.S.H.
